abstract.p: Letter from Dean W Hestermann, director of government relations for Harrah's Entertainment, holds gambling industry shares desire of Jim Calhoun, men's basketball coach at University of Connecticut, to crack down on campus bookies who prey on college athletes (Sept 27 Op-Ed); contends that Calhoun's solution--banning betting on college sports at Nevada casinos--misses the target

block.p: The casino industry shares the desire of Jim Calhoun, the men's basketball coach at the University of Connecticut, to crack down on campus bookies who prey on college athletes (Op-Ed, Sept. 27). But Mr. Calhoun's solution -- banning betting on college sports at Nevada casinos -- misses the target.

The casino industry shares the desire of Jim Calhoun, the men's basketball coach at the University of Connecticut, to crack down on campus bookies who prey on college athletes (Op-Ed, Sept. 27). But Mr. Calhoun's solution -- banning betting on college sports at Nevada casinos -- misses the target.

Millions of people travel to Nevada each year to enjoy betting on events like college football bowl games and the basketball Final Four. These regulated and taxed bets account for a tiny fraction of all wagers on college sports, and they don't threaten the integrity of college games. If the proposed ban were enacted, betting lines on college games would continue to be set, illegal bets would still be placed on campus, and illegal gambling would be driven further underground.
The writer is director of government relations for Harrah's Entertainment.
